# Resupply from another warehouse

A common use case for multiple warehouses is to have one central
warehouse that resupplies multiple shops, and in this case, each shop is
considered a local warehouse. When a shop wants to replenish a product,
the product is ordered to the central warehouse. Odoo allows the user to
easily set which warehouse(s) can resupply another warehouse.

## Configuration

To resupply from another warehouse, first go to
`Inventory --> Configuration -->
Settings --> Warehouse`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"} and
activate `Multi-Step Routes`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. Then,
click `Save`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to apply the setting.

![Enable Multi-Step Routes in Inventory settings.](resupply_warehouses/virtual-warehouses-settings.png){.align-center}

View all the configured warehouses by going to
`Inventory --> Configuration -->
Warehouses`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}.

Create a new warehouse by clicking `Create`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}. Then, give the warehouse a name and a
`Short Name`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. Finally, click
`Save`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to finish creating the
warehouse.

After that, go back to the `Warehouses`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} page and open the warehouse that will be resupplied by
the second warehouse. Then, click `Edit`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}. In the `Warehouse
Configuration`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab, locate the
`Resupply From`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field, and check the
box next to the second warehouse\'s name. If the warehouse can be
resupplied by more than one warehouse, make sure to check those
warehouses\' boxes too. Finally, click `Save`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} to apply the setting. Now, Odoo knows which warehouses
can resupply this warehouse.

![Supply one warehouse with another in the Warehouse Configuration tab.](resupply_warehouses/resupply-from-second-warehouse.png){.align-center}

## Set route on a product

After configuring which warehouse(s) to resupply from, a new route is
now available on all product forms. The new route appears as
`Supply Product from [Warehouse Name]`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} under the `Inventory`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} tab on a product form. Use the
`Supply Product from [Warehouse
Name]`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} route with a reordering rule
or the make to order (MTO) route to replenish stock by moving the
product from one warehouse to another.

![Route setting which enables a product to resupplied from a second warehouse.](resupply_warehouses/product-resupply-route-settings.png){.align-center}

When a product\'s reordering rule is triggered and the product has the
`Supply Product
from [Warehouse Name]`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} route set,
Odoo automatically creates two pickings. One picking is a *delivery
order* from the second warehouse, which contains all the necessary
products, and the second picking is a *receipt* with the same products
for the main warehouse. The product move from the second warehouse to
the main warehouse is fully tracked in Odoo.

On the picking/transfer records created by Odoo, the
`Source Document`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} is the product\'s
reordering rule. The location between the delivery order and the receipt
is a transit location.

![A reordering rule automatically creates two receipts for stock between warehouses.](resupply_warehouses/resupply-receipts-from-reordering-rule.png){.align-center}

![A warehouse order for resupplying one warehouse\'s stock with another.](resupply_warehouses/second-warehouse-delivery-order.png){.align-center}

![A receipt for stock received to one warehouse from another.](resupply_warehouses/second-warehouse-stock-receipt.png){.align-center}




--- SOURCE: inventory_and_mrp/inventory/warehouses_storage/replenishment/warehouse_replenishment_transfer.md ---

# Transfer products between warehouses using replenishment

For companies that use multiple warehouses, it is often necessary to
transfer items between them. This is referred to as an *inter-warehouse
transfer*. Odoo *Inventory* handles the administrative process of
inter-warehouse transfers to ensure that inventory counts remain
accurate during and after the transfer. This document will detail the
method for conducting an inter-warehouse transfer using replenishment.

## Configure warehouses for inter-warehouse replenishment

First, ensure the `Multi-Step Routes`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
setting is enabled by navigating to
`Inventory --> Configuration --> Settings`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}, and then check the box under the
`Warehouse`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab. This will provide
additional configuration options when creating a second warehouse that
are needed for inter-warehouse replenishment.

By default, Odoo comes with a main warehouse already configured. If an
additional warehouse has not already been created, do so now from the
`Inventory`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} module by selecting
`Configuration --> Warehouses --> Create`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}. Otherwise, select the warehouse that products
will be transferred to from the `Warehouses`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} page and then click `Edit`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} to change its settings. Configure the warehouse as
follows:

- `Warehouse`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: choose a name that is
  not already being used for another warehouse (e.g. [Alternative
  Warehouse]{.title-ref})
- `Short Name`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: choose a short name
  by which the warehouse will be identified (e.g. [ALT_WH]{.title-ref})

Click `Save`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} and the new warehouse
will be created. In addition, a new `Resupply
From`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field will appear on the
warehouse\'s form. Click `Edit`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} and
then check the box next to the warehouse that will be used to resupply
the warehouse that is currently being configured.

![A warehouse settings form configured to allow resupplying between warehouses.](warehouse_replenishment_transfer/new-warehouse-configuration.png){.align-center}

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

For the purposes of this demonstration, the warehouse that products are
transferred from (outgoing) will be titled \"San Francisco\", and the
warehouse that products are transferred to (incoming) will be titled
\"San Francisco 2\".
::::

## Configure products for inter-warehouse replenishment

Products must also be configured properly in order for them to be
transferred between warehouses. Navigate to
`Inventory --> Products --> Products`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"} and select an existing product or
`Create`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} a new one, if necessary.

Then, on the product form, go to the `Inventory`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} tab and enable the checkbox for
`X: Supply Product from Y`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, with *X*
being the warehouse receiving the transferred products and *Y* being the
warehouse that products are transferred from.

![Enable the checkbox to resupply one warehouse from another.](warehouse_replenishment_transfer/product-transfer-configuration.png){.align-center}

## Replenish one warehouse from another

Starting in the `Inventory`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}
module, select `Products --> Products`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"} and then choose the product that will be
replenished. Click the `Replenish`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
button on the top left of the product page and fill out the pop-up form
as follows:

- `Quantity`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: the number of units
  that will be sent to the warehouse being replenished
- `Scheduled Date`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: the date that the
  replenishment is scheduled to take place
- `Warehouse`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: the warehouse that
  will be replenished
- `Preferred Routes`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: select [X:
  Supply Product from Y]{.title-ref}, with *X* being the warehouse to be
  replenished and *Y* being the warehouse that the product will be
  transferred from

![The form for replenishing a product.](warehouse_replenishment_transfer/product-replenishment-form.png){.align-center}

Click `Confirm`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} and a delivery order
will be created for the outgoing warehouse along with a receipt for the
warehouse that will receive the product. Depending on the configuration
settings for the outgoing and incoming warehouses, processing delivery
orders and receipts will require between one and three steps. This
document will detail how to process one-step deliveries and receipts.

### Process the delivery order

The first stage of a replenishment order is processing the delivery from
the warehouse that the product is being transferred from. On the
`Inventory`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"} dashboard, select
the `X to Process`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} button on the
`Delivery Orders`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} card for the
outgoing warehouse, then the delivery order created for the
replenishment. On the delivery order page, click the
`Check Availability`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} button in the
top left to reserve the quantity of the product to be transferred. Once
the delivery has been dispatched, click the `Validate`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} button to register the quantities shipped.

![The delivery orders card for the outgoing warehouse.](warehouse_replenishment_transfer/delivery-orders-card.png){.align-center}

### Process the receipt

Once the goods arrive at the incoming warehouse, the receipt created for
that warehouse must be processed as well. Return to the
`Inventory`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"} dashboard and select
the `X to
Process`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} button on the
`Receipts`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} card for the incoming
warehouse, then the receipt created for the replenishment. On the
receipt page, click the `Validate`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
button in the top left of the page to register the quantities received.

![The delivery orders card for the outgoing warehouse.](warehouse_replenishment_transfer/receipts-card.png){.align-center}

After processing the receipt, the products transferred will now appear
in the inventory of the incoming warehouse. The stock numbers for both
warehouses can be viewed by returning to the product page and selecting
the `X Units On Hand`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} button at the
top of the screen.

## Automate inter-warehouse replenishment

Using reordering rules, it is possible to automate the process of
replenishing one warehouse from another.

To get started, navigate to
`Inventory --> Products --> Products`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}, and then choose the product that will be
replenished. From the product page, select the `Reordering
Rules`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} smart button at the top of the
form, and then on the next page, click `Create`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} to configure the form as follows:

- `Location`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: the location that the
  reordering rule will replenish when triggered, in this case, the
  incoming warehouse
- `Min Quantity`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: when the quantity
  on hand at the incoming warehouse falls below this number, the
  reordering rule will be triggered
- `Max Quantity`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: when the reordering
  rule is triggered, the product will be replenished at the incoming
  warehouse up to this quantity
- `Multiple Quantity`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: specify if the
  product should be replenished in batches of a certain quantity; for
  example, a product could be replenished in batches of 20
- `UoM`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: the unit of measure used for
  reordering the product; this value can simply be [Units]{.title-ref},
  or a specific unit of measurement for weight, length, etc.

![A fully configured reordering rule.](warehouse_replenishment_transfer/reordering-rule-configuration.png){.align-center}

Finish by clicking `Save`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} and the
reordering rule will be created. Now, when the scheduler runs
automatically each day, a transfer will be created for each reordering
rule that has been triggered.

:::: tip
::: title
Tip
:::

To manually trigger reordering rules, start from the
`Inventory`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"} module and select
`Operation --> Run Scheduler`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"},
then click the green `Run Scheduler`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
button in the pop-up that appears.
::::

After the scheduler runs, a delivery order and receipt will be created
for the outgoing and incoming warehouses, respectively. Both the
delivery order and receipt should be processed using the same method as
detailed above.




--- SOURCE: inventory_and_mrp/inventory/warehouses_storage/replenishment.md ---

show-content

:   

hide-page-toc

:   

# Replenishment

In Odoo, stock can be replenished one of three ways: *reordering rules*,
the *make to order* (MTO) route, or using the *master production
schedule* (MPS).

Each replenishment mechanism triggers the creation or suggestion of a
purchase order (PO) or manufacturing order (MO), with the best choice
depending on the business process.

:::::: cards
::: {.card target="replenishment/reordering_rules" tag="Recommended" large=""}
Reordering rules

Automatically suggest or generate POs or MOs when stock falls below a
minimum level.
:::

::: {.card target="replenishment/mto" tag="Beginner-friendly"}
MTO

Automatically generate POs or MOs when sales orders are confirmed.
:::

::: {.card target="../../manufacturing/management/use_mps"}
MPS

Manage long-term replenishment based on inputted sales forecasts, via a
dashboard.
:::
::::::

## Replenishment strategies

### Replenishment report and reordering rules

Reordering rules are rules that can be set up to maintain a minimum
stock level. They are often configured to support manufacturing or sales
requirements. When a product\'s stock falls at or below the minimum
level, Odoo generates (or suggests) a purchase or manufacturing order to
replenish stock to the maximum level.

When using automatic reordering rules, Odoo generates a new order. When
using manual, Odoo suggests orders on the replenishment report. For
detailed guidance, refer to the `replenishment report
<replenishment/report>`{.interpreted-text role="doc"} and
`reordering rules <replenishment/reordering_rules>`{.interpreted-text
role="doc"}.

Key points include:

- `Automatic reordering rules <inventory/warehouses_storage/auto-rr>`{.interpreted-text
  role="ref"}: Automatically create
  `POs (Purchase Orders)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} or
  `MOs (Manufacturing Orders)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} when stock
  falls below the minimum level. While this is convenient, it is less
  flexible.
- `Manual reordering rules <inventory/warehouses_storage/manual-rr>`{.interpreted-text
  role="ref"}: Generate suggestions in the replenishment report for user
  review, allowing adjustments and batch orders while meeting deadlines.
- `Just-in-time logic <inventory/warehouses_storage/just-in-time>`{.interpreted-text
  role="ref"}: A strategy to replenish only what is needed to prevent
  overstocking.

::: seealso
\- `replenishment/reordering_rules`{.interpreted-text role="doc"} -
`replenishment/report`{.interpreted-text role="doc"}
:::

### Make to order {#inventory/management/products/strategies}

An `MTO (Make to Oder)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} strategy means
that procurement or production is triggered only after a sales order has
been confirmed. This strategy is recommended when products are
customizable, demand is unpredictable, there is limited storage
capacity, and when products are high in value and low in demand. In such
cases, it does not make sense to keep on-hand inventory.

Unlike products replenished using reordering rules, Odoo automatically
links the sales order to the `PO (Purchase Order)`{.interpreted-text
role="abbr"} or `MO (Manufacturing Order)`{.interpreted-text
role="abbr"} generated by the `MTO (Make to Oder)`{.interpreted-text
role="abbr"} route.

Another difference between reordering rules and
`MTO (Make to Oder)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} is, with
`MTO (Make to Oder)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}, Odoo generates a
draft `PO (Purchase Order)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} or
`MO (Manufacturing Order)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} immediately
after the `SO (Sales Order)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} is
confirmed. With reordering rules, Odoo generates a draft
`PO (Purchase Order)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} or
`MO (Manufacturing Order)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} when the
product\'s forecasted stock falls below the set minimum quantity.

In addition, Odoo automatically adds quantities to the
`PO (Purchase Order)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} or
`MO (Manufacturing Order)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} as the
forecast changes, so long as the `PO (Purchase Order)`{.interpreted-text
role="abbr"} or `MO (Manufacturing Order)`{.interpreted-text
role="abbr"} is not confirmed.

The `MTO (Make to Oder)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} route is the
best replenishment strategy for products that are customized, and/or for
products that have no stock kept on-hand.

::: seealso
`replenishment/mto`{.interpreted-text role="doc"}
:::

### Master production schedule

The `MPS (Master Production Schedule)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} is
a dashboard where products and their forecasted quantities are entered.
Based on confirmed manufacturing and purchase orders, the dashboard
recommends amounts to order or produce.

This a useful **manual** tool for keeping track of quantities. The
`MPS (Master Production
Schedule)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} **should absolutely not** be
used alongside reordering rules, as the automated workflow disrupts its
manual replenishment method.

::: seealso
`../../manufacturing/management/use_mps`{.interpreted-text role="doc"}
:::

::: {.toctree titlesonly=""}
replenishment/mto replenishment/reordering_rules replenishment/report
replenishment/lead_times replenishment/resupply_warehouses
replenishment/warehouse_replenishment_transfer
:::

# Add new equipment

::: {#maintenance/equipment_management/add_new_equipment}
In Odoo, *equipment* refers to any item that is used in everyday
operations, including the manufacturing of products. This can mean a
piece of machinery on a production line, a tool that is used in
different locations, or a computer in an office space. Equipment
registered in Odoo can be owned by the company that uses the Odoo
database, or by a third party, such as a vendor in the case of equipment
rentals.
:::

Using Odoo *Maintenance*, it is possible to track individual pieces of
equipment, along with information about their maintenance requirements.
To add a new piece of equipment, navigate to the
`Maintenance`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} module, select
`Equipments --> Machines & Tools --> Create`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}, and configure the equipment as follows:

- `Equipment Name`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: the product name
  of the piece of equipment
- `Equipment Category`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: the category
  that the equipment belongs to; for example, computers, machinery,
  tools, etc.; new categories can be created by navigating to
  `Configuration --> Equipment Categories`{.interpreted-text
  role="menuselection"} and clicking `Create`{.interpreted-text
  role="guilabel"}
- `Company`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: the company that owns
  the equipment; again, this can be the company that uses the Odoo
  database, or a third-party company
- `Used By`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: specify if the equipment
  is used by a specific employee, department, or both; select
  `Other`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to specify both an employee
  and a department
- `Maintenance Team`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: the team
  responsible for servicing the equipment; new teams can be created by
  navigating to `Configuration --> Maintenance Teams`{.interpreted-text
  role="menuselection"} and selecting `Create`{.interpreted-text
  role="guilabel"}; the members of each team can also be assigned from
  this page
- `Technician`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: the person
  responsible for servicing the equipment; this can be used to assign a
  specific individual in the event that no maintenance team is assigned
  or when a specific member of the assigned team should always be
  responsible for the equipment; any person added to Odoo as a user can
  be assigned as a technician
- `Used in location`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: the location
  where the equipment is used; this is a simple text field that can be
  used to specify locations that are not work centers, like an office,
  for example
- `Work Center`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: if the equipment is
  used at a work center, specify it here; equipment can also be assigned
  to a work center by navigating to `Maintenance --> Equipments -->
  Work Centers`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}, selecting a
  work center or creating a new one using the `Create`{.interpreted-text
  role="guilabel"} button, and clicking the
  `Equipment`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab on the work center
  form

![An example of a fully configured new equipment form.](add_new_equipment/new-equipment-form.png){.align-center}

## Include additional product information

The `Product Information`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab at the
bottom of the form can be used to provide further details about the
piece of equipment:

- `Vendor`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: the vendor that the
  equipment was purchased from
- `Vendor Reference`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: the reference
  code assigned to the vendor
- `Model`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: the specific model of the
  piece of equipment
- `Serial Number`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: the unique serial
  number of the equipment
- `Effective Date`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: the date that the
  equipment became available for use; this is used to calculate the
  `MTBF (Mean Time Between Failures)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}
- `Cost`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: the amount the equipment
  was purchased for
- `Warranty Expiration Date`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: the
  date on which the equipment\'s warranty will expire

![The product information tab for the new piece of equipment.](add_new_equipment/new-equipment-product-information.png){.align-center}

## Add maintenance details

The `Maintenance`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab includes
information that can be useful to maintenance teams:

- `Preventive Maintenance Frequency`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}:
  specifies how often maintenance should be performed to prevent
  equipment failure
- `Maintenance Duration`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: the amount
  of time required to fix the equipment when it fails
- `Expected Mean Time Between Failure`{.interpreted-text
  role="guilabel"}: the average amount of time that the equipment is
  expected to operate before failing

![The maintenance tab for the new piece of equipment.](add_new_equipment/new-equipment-maintenance.png){.align-center}

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

The `Maintenance`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab also includes
sections for `Mean Time Between Failure`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}, `Estimated Next Failure`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}, `Latest Failure`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
and `Mean Time To Repair`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. These
values are calculated automatically based on maintenance requests if any
exist.
::::

:::: tip
::: title
Tip
:::

To see the maintenance requests for a piece of equipment, go to the page
for the equipment and select `Maintenance`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} in the top right corner of the form.
::::
