# Use blanket orders to create purchase agreements with vendors

Blanket orders are long-term purchase agreements between a company and a
vendor to deliver products on a recurring basis with predetermined
pricing. Using blanket orders are useful when products are always
purchased from the same vendor, but in different quantities at different
times.

By simplifying the ordering process, blanket orders not only save time,
they also save money, since they can be advantageous when negotiating
bulk pricing with vendors.

::: seealso
`calls_for_tenders`{.interpreted-text role="doc"}
:::

## Create a new blanket order

To create blanket orders, the *Purchase Agreements* feature first needs
to be enabled in the settings of the *Purchase* app. To do this, go to
`Purchase --> Configuration -->
Settings`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}, and under the
`Orders`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} section, click the checkbox
next to `Purchase
Agreements`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. Doing so will enable the
ability to create blanket orders, as well as alternative requests for
quotation (RFQs).

![Purchase Agreements enabled in the Purshase app settings.](blanket_orders/blanket-orders-settings-page.png){.align-center}

To create a blanket order, go to
`Purchase --> Orders --> blanket orders`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}, and click `New`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}. This creates (and navigates to) a new blanket order
form.

From this new blanket order form, different fields and settings can be
configured, so there are pre-determined rules that the recurring
long-term agreement must follow:

- `Purchase Representative`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: is the
  user assigned to this specific blanket order. By default, this is the
  user who created the agreement; the user can be changed directly from
  the drop-down menu next to this field.
- `Agreement Type`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: is the type of
  purchase agreement this blanket order is classified as. In Odoo,
  blanket orders are the only official purchase agreement.
- `Vendor`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: is the supplier to whom
  this agreement is tied, either once or on a recurring basis. The
  vendor can be selected directly from the drop-down menu next to this
  field.
- `Currency`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: is the agreed-upon
  currency that will be used for this exchange. If multiple currencies
  have been activated in the database, the currency can be changed from
  the drop-down menu next to this field.
- `Agreement Deadline`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: is the date
  that this purchase agreement will be set to expire on (if desired). If
  this blanket order should not expire, leave this field blank.
- `Ordering Date`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: is the date that
  this blanket order should be placed on if a new quotation is created
  directly from the blanket order form. If a new quotation is created,
  this value will automatically populate the *Order Deadline* field on
  the `RFQ (Request for
  Quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}.
- `Delivery Date`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: is the expected
  delivery date that the products included in an
  `RFQ (Request for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} created
  directly from the blanket order form will be expected to arrive. If a
  new quotation is created, this value will automatically populate the
  *Expected Arrival* field on the
  `RFQ (Request for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}.
- `Source Document`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: is the source
  purchase order (PO) that this blanket order will be tied to. If this
  blanket order should not be tied to any existing
  `POs (Purchase Orders)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}, leave this
  field blank.
- `Company`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: is the company assigned
  to this specific blanket order. By default, this is the company that
  the user creating the blanket order is listed under. If the database
  is not a multi-company database, this field can not be changed, and
  will default to the only company listed in the database.

![New blanket order purchase agreement with added products.](blanket_orders/blanket-orders-new-agreement.png){.align-center}

Once all relevant fields have been filled out, click
`Add a line`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to add products under
the `Product`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} column. Then, change
the quantity of each product in the `Quantity`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} column (if desired), and set a price in the
`Unit Price`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} column.

:::: important
::: title
Important
:::

When adding products to a new blanket order, the pre-existing prices of
products will not be added automatically to the product lines. The
prices must be manually assigned by changing the value in the
`Unit Price`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} column to an agreed-upon
price with the listed vendor. Otherwise, the price will remain **0**.
::::

To view and change the default purchase agreement settings for blanket
orders directly from the blanket order form, click the
`internal link (arrow icon)`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} next to
the `Agreement Type`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field where
`Blanket Order`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} is listed. This
navigates to the blanket order settings.

From here, the settings for blanket orders can be edited. Under the
`Agreement Type`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} section, the name of
the `Agreement Type`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} can be changed
(if desired), and the `Agreement Selection Type`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} can be changed, as well. There are two options that can
be activated for the type of selection:

- `Select only one RFQ (exclusive)`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}:
  when a purchase order is confirmed, the remaining purchase orders will
  be canceled.
- `Select multiple RFQ (non-exclusive)`{.interpreted-text
  role="guilabel"}: when a purchase order is confirmed, remaining
  purchase orders will **\*not** be canceled. Instead, multiple purchase
  orders are allowed.

Under the `Data For New Quotations`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
section, the settings for how product lines and quantities will be
populated on new quotations using this purchase agreeement can be
changed next to the `Lines`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} and
`Quantities`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} fields.

![Purchase Agreement type edit screen for blanket orders.](blanket_orders/blanket-orders-edit-agreement-type.png){.align-center}

There are two options that can be activated for
`Lines`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}:

- `Use lines of agreement`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: when
  creating a new quotation, the product lines will pre-populate with the
  same products listed on the blanket order, if said blanket order is
  chosen on the new quotation.
- `Do not create RfQ lines automatically`{.interpreted-text
  role="guilabel"}: when creating a new quotation and selecting an
  existing blanket order, the settings will carry over to the new
  quotation, but the product lines will not populate.

And, there are two options that can be activated for
`Quantities`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}:

- `Use quantities of agreement`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: when
  creating a new quotation, the product quantities listed on the blanket
  order will pre-populate on the product lines, if said blanket order is
  chosen on the new quotation.
- `Set quantities manually`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: when
  creating a new quotation and selecting an existing blanket order, the
  product lines will pre-populate, but all quantities will be set to
  **0**. The quantities will need to be manually set by the user.

Once the desired changes have been made (if any), click
`New`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} (via the breadcrumbs, at the
top of the page) to navigate back to the blanket order form, and click
`Confirm`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to save this new purchase
agreement. Once confirmed, the blanket order changes from *Draft* to
*Ongoing*, meaning this agreement can be selected and used when creating
new `RFQs (Requests
for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}.

:::: tip
::: title
Tip
:::

After creating and confirming a blanket order, products, quantities, and
prices can still be edited, added, and removed from the purchase
agreement.
::::

## Create a new `RFQ (Request for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} from the blanket order

After confirming a blanket order, new quotations can be created directly
from the blanket order form that will use the rules set on the form and
pre-populate the new quotation with the correct information.
Additionally, this new quotation will be automatically linked to this
blanket order form via the `RFQs/Orders`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} smart button at the top right of the form.

To create a new quotation from the blanket order form, click
`New Quotation`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. This creates (and
navigates to) a new `RFQ (Request for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text
role="abbr"}, that is pre-populated with the correct information,
depending on the settings configured on the blanket order form.

From the new `RFQ (Request for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text
role="abbr"} form, click `Send by Email`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} to compose and send an email to the listed vendor;
click `Print RFQ`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to generate a
printable PDF of the quotation; or, once ready, click
`Confirm Order`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to confirm the
purchase order (PO).

![New quotation with copied products and rules from blanket order.](blanket_orders/blanket-orders-new-quotation.png){.align-center}

Once the `PO (Purchase Order)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} has been
confirmed, click back to the blanket order form (via the breadcrumbs, at
the top of the page). From the blanket order form, there is now one `RFQ
(Request for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} listed in the
`RFQs/Orders`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} smart button at the top
right of the form. Click the `RFQs/Orders`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} smart button to see the purchase order that was just
created.

![RFQs and Orders smart button from blanket order form.](blanket_orders/blanket-orders-rfq-smart-button.png){.align-center}

## Create a new blanket order from an `RFQ (Request for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}

To create a new `RFQ (Request for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text
role="abbr"}, navigate to the `Purchase`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"} app, and click `New`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}.

Then, add information to the
`RFQ (Request for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} form: add a
vendor from the drop-down menu next to the `Vendor`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} field, and click `Add a product`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} to select a product from the drop-down menu in the
`Product`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} column. Then, set the
desired purchase quantity in the `Quantity`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} column, and change the purchase price in the `Unit
Price`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} column, if desired.

Clicking the `additional options (two-dots)`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} icon provides additional visibility options to add to
the line item. Repeat these steps to add as many additional options as
desired, including the `UoM`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} (Units
of Measure) to purchase the products in, and the `Expected
Arrival`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} date.

Before confirming the new quotation and creating a purchase order, click
the drop-down menu next to the `Blanket Order`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} field, and type a new name for the new blanket order.
This creates a brand new purchase agreement, and saves the information
entered in the fields of the purchase order form, as well as the product
information entered on the product lines.

From the new `RFQ (Request for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text
role="abbr"} form, click `Send by Email`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} to compose and send an email to the listed vendor;
click `Print RFQ`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to generate a
printable PDF of the quotation; or, once ready, click
`Confirm Order`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to confirm the
`PO (purchase
order)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}.

![New blanket order created directly from quotation.](blanket_orders/blanket-orders-new-blanket-order.png){.align-center}

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

To see the newly-created blanket order purchase agreement, go to
`Orders -->
Blanket Orders`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}, and click into
the new blanket order. From here, settings and rules can be changed, if
desired.
::::

## Blanket orders and replenishment

Once a blanket order is confirmed, a new vendor line is added under the
`Purchase`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab of of the products
included in the `BO (Blanket Order)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}.
This makes blanket orders useful with
`automated replenishment <../../purchase/products/reordering>`{.interpreted-text
role="doc"}, because information about the `Vendor`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}, `Price`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and the
`Agreement`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} are referenced on the
vendor line. This information is used to determine where, when, and for
what price this product could be replenished.

![Product form with replenishment agreement linked to blanket order.](blanket_orders/blanket-orders-automated-replenishment.png){.align-center}




--- SOURCE: inventory_and_mrp/purchase/manage_deals/calls_for_tenders.md ---

# Create alternative requests for quotation for multiple vendors

Sometimes, companies might want to request offers from multiple vendors
at the same time, by inviting those vendors to submit offers for similar
goods or services all at once. This helps companies to select the
cheapest (and fastest) vendors, depending on their specific business
needs.

In Odoo, this can be done by adding alternative requests for quotation
(RFQs) for different vendors. Once a response is received from each
vendor, the product lines from each `RFQ
(Request for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} can be compared,
and a decision can be made for which products to purchase from which
vendors.

Sometimes referred to as a *call for tender*, this process is primarily
used by organizations in the public sector, who are legally bound to use
it when making a purchase. However, private companies can also use
alternative `RFQs (Requests for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text
role="abbr"} to spend money efficiently, as well.

::: seealso
`blanket_orders`{.interpreted-text role="doc"}
:::

## Configure purchase agreement settings

To create alternative `RFQs (Requests for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text
role="abbr"} directly from a quotation, the *Purchase Agreements*
feature first needs to be enabled in the settings of the *Purchase* app.
To do this, go to
`Purchase --> Configuration --> Settings`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}, and under the `Orders`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} section, click the checkbox next to
`Purchase Agreements`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. Doing so will
enable the ability to create alternative
`RFQs (Requests for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}, as well
as the ability to create *blanket orders*.

![Purchase Agreements enabled in the Purchase app settings.](calls_for_tenders/calls-for-tenders-settings-page.png){.align-center}

:::: tip
::: title
Tip
:::

To save time on a *call for tender*, custom vendors, prices, and
delivery lead times can be set in the `Purchase`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} tab on a product form. To do so, navigate to
`Purchase --> Products --> Products`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}, and select a product to edit. From the product
form, click the `Purchase tab`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, then
click `Add a line`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. From the
drop-down menu, choose a vendor to set under the
`Vendor`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} column, and set a
`Price`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} and
`Delivery Lead Time`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} if desired.
Clicking the `additional options (two-dots)`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} icon provides additional visibility options to add to
the line item.
::::

## Create an `RFQ (Request for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}

To create a new `RFQ (Request for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text
role="abbr"}, navigate to the `Purchase`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"} app, and click `New`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}.

Then, add information to the
`RFQ (Request for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} form: add a
vendor from the drop-down next to the `Vendor`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} field, and click `Add a product`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} to select a product from the drop-down menu in the
`Product`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} column. Then, set the
desired purchase quantity in the `Quantity`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} column, and change the purchase price in the `Unit
Price`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} column, if desired.

Clicking the `additional options (two-dots)`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} icon provides additional visibility options to add to
the line item. Repeat these steps to add as many options as desired,
including the `UoM`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} (Units of
Measure) to purchase the products in, and the
`Expected Arrival`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} date.

Once ready, click `Send by Email`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.
This causes a `Compose Email`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} pop-up
window to appear, wherein the message to the vendor can be customized.
Once ready, click `Send`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. This turns
the `RFQ (Request for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} into a
purchase order (PO), and sends an email to the vendor listed on the
purchase order form.

![Compose and send quotation email pop-up.](calls_for_tenders/calls-for-tenders-email-popup.png){.align-center}

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

Sending emails to each vendor can be useful when creating alternative
`RFQs (Requests for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}, because
vendors can confirm if their past prices still hold today, which can
help companies choose the best offers for them.
::::

## Create alternatives to an `RFQ (Request for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}

Once a `PO (Purchase Order)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} is created
and sent by email to a vendor, alternative `RFQs
(Requests for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} can be created
and sent to additional, alternate vendors to compare prices, delivery
times, and other factors to make a decision from which vendors to order
which products.

To create alternative `RFQs (Requests for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text
role="abbr"}, click the `Alternatives`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} tab from the purchase order form, then click
`Create Alternative`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. When clicked, a
`Create alternative`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} pop-up window
appears.

![Calls for tenders pop-up to create alternative quotation.](calls_for_tenders/calls-for-tenders-alternatives-popup.png){.align-center}

From this window, select a new/different vendor from the drop-down menu
next to the `Vendor`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field to assign
this alternative quotation to.

Next to this, there is a `Copy Products`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} checkbox that is selected by default. When selected,
the product quantities of the original
`PO (Purchase Order)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} are copied to the
alternative. For this first alternative quotation, leave the checkbox
checked. Once finished, click `Create Alternative`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}. This creates (and navigates to) a new
`PO (Purchase Order)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}.

Since the `Create Alternative`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
checkbox was left checked, this new purchase order form is already
populated with the same products, quantities, and other details as the
previous, original `PO (Purchase Order)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

When the `Copy Products`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} checkbox is
selected while creating an alternative quotation, additional products do
not need to be added on the purchase order form unless desired. However,
if a chosen vendor is listed in the `Vendor`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} column under the `Purchase`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} tab on a product form included in the purchase order,
the values set on the product form carry over to the
`PO (Purchase Order)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}, and have to be
changed manually, if desired.
::::

Once ready, create a second alternative quotation by clicking the
`Alternatives`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab, and once again,
click `Create Alternative`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. This
causes the `Create alternative`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
pop-up window to appear again. This time, choose a different vendor from
the drop-down menu next to `Vendor`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
and this time, *uncheck* the `Copy Products`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} checkbox. Then, click
`Create Alternative`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

:::: tip
::: title
Tip
:::

If an alternative quotation needs to be removed from the
`Alternatives`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab, they can be
individually removed by clicking on the `Remove (X)`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} icon at the end of their row.
::::

This creates a third, new purchase order. But, since the product
quantities of the original `PO (Purchase Order)`{.interpreted-text
role="abbr"} were *not* copied over, the product lines are empty, and
new products need to be added by clicking
`Add a product`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and selecting the
desired products from the drop-down menu. Once the desired number of
products are added, click `Send by Email`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}.

![Blank alternative quotation with alternatives in breadcrumbs.](calls_for_tenders/calls-for-tenders-blank-alternative.png){.align-center}

This causes a `Compose Email`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} pop-up
window to appear, wherein the message to the vendor can be customized.
Once ready, click `Send`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to send an
email to the vendor listed on the purchase order form.

From this newest purchase order form, click the
`Alternatives`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab. Under this tab,
all three purchase orders can be seen in the
`Reference`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} column. Additionally, the
vendors are listed under the `Vendor`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
column, and the order `Total`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} and
`Status`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} of the orders are in the
rows, as well.

## Link a new `RFQ (Request for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} to existing quotations

Creating alternative quotations directly from a purchase order form
under the `Alternatives`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab is the
easiest way to create and link quotations. However, separate
`RFQs (Requests for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} can also
be linked *after* the fact, even if they are created completely
separately at first.

To create a new `RFQ (Request for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text
role="abbr"}, navigate to the `Purchase`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"} app, and click `New`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}.

Then, add information to the
`RFQ (Request for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} form: add a
vendor from the drop-down next to the `Vendor`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} field, and click `Add a product`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} to select a product from the drop-down menu in the
`Product`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} column. Then, set the
desired purchase quantity in the `Quantity`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} column, and change the purchase price in the
`Unit Price`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} column, if desired.

Once ready, click `Send by Email`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.
This causes a `Compose Email`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} pop-up
window to appear, wherein the message to the vendor can be customized.
Once ready, click `Send`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to send an
email to the vendor listed on the purchase order form.

Then, click the `Alternatives`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab
once more. Since this new `PO (Purchase Order)`{.interpreted-text
role="abbr"} was created separately, there are no other orders linked
yet. To link this order with the alternatives created previously, click
`Link to Existing RfQ`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} on the first
line in the `Vendor`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} column.

![pop-up to link new quotation to existing RFQs.](calls_for_tenders/calls-for-tenders-link-existing-rfq.png){.align-center}

This causes an `Add: Alternative POs`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
pop-up window to appear. Select the three purchase orders created
previously, and click `Select`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. All
of these orders are now copied to this
`PO (Purchase Order)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} under the
`Alternatives`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab.

:::: tip
::: title
Tip
:::

If a large number of purchase orders are being processed and the
previous `POs (Purchase Orders)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} can\'t
be located, try clicking `Group By -->
Vendor`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"} under the search bar at
the top of the pop-up window to group by the vendors selected on the
previous orders.
::::

## Compare product lines

When there are multiple
`RFQs (Requests for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} linked as
alternatives, they can be compared side-by-side in order to determine
which vendors offer the best deals on which products. To compare each
quotation, go to the `Purchase`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}
app, and select one of the quotations created previously.

Then, click the `Alternatives`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab to
see all the linked `RFQs (Requests for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text
role="abbr"}. Next, under the `Create Alternative`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} tab, click `Compare Product Lines`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}. This navigates to a Compare Order Lines page.

![Compare Product Lines page for alternative RFQs.](calls_for_tenders/calls-for-tenders-compare-product-lines.png){.align-center}

The Compare Order Lines page, by default, groups by
`Product`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. Each product included in
any of the `RFQs (Requests for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text
role="abbr"} is displayed in its own drop-down, along with all of the
`PO (Purchase Order)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} numbers in the
`Reference`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} column.

Additional columns on this page include the `Vendor`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} from which products were ordered, the
`Status`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} of the quotation (i.e., RFQ,
RFQ Sent); the `Quantity`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} of products
ordered from each vendor; the `Unit Price`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} per product and `Total`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} price of the order, and more.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

To remove product lines from the Compare Order Lines page, click
`Clear`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} at the far right end of that
product line\'s row. This removes this product as a chooseable option
from the page, and changes the `Total`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} price of that product on the page to **0**. On the
purchase order form in which that product was included, its ordered
quantity is changed to **0**, as well.
::::

Once the best offers have been identified, at the end of each row,
individual products can be selected by clicking
`Choose`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. Once all the desired
products have been chosen, click
`Requests for Quotation`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} (in the
breadcrumbs, at the top of the page) to navigate back to an overview of
all `RFQs (Requests for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}.

## Cancel (or keep) alternatives

Now that the desired products have been chosen, based on which vendors
provided the best offer, the other
`RFQs (Requests for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} (from
which no products were chosen) can be canceled.

Under the `Total`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} column, at the far
right of each row, the orders from which no products were chosen have
automatically had their total cost set to **0**. Although they haven\'t
been canceled yet, this means that they can ultimately be canceled
without repercussions, *after* the desired purchase orders have been
confirmed.

![Canceled quotations in the Purchase app overview.](calls_for_tenders/calls-for-tenders-canceled-quotes.png){.align-center}

To confirm a quotation that contains the chosen product quantities,
click into one. Then, click `Confirm Order`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}. This causes an `Alternative Warning`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} pop-up window to appear. From there, either
`Cancel Alternatives`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} or
`Keep Alternatives`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} can be clicked.
If this `PO (Purchase Order)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} should
*not* be confirmed, click `Cancel`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

`Cancel Alternatives`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} automatically
cancels the alternative purchase orders.
`Keep Alternatives`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} keeps the
alternative purchase orders open, so they can still be accessed if any
additional product quantities need to be ordered. Once all products are
ordered, `Cancel Alternatives`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} can be
selected from whichever `PO (Purchase Order)`{.interpreted-text
role="abbr"} is open.

To view a detailed form of one of the
`RFQs (Requests for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} listed,
click the line item for that quotation. This causes an
`Open: Alternative POs`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} pop-up window
to appear, from which all details of that particular quotation can be
viewed. Click `Close`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} when finished.

![Keep or cancel pop-up for alternative RFQs.](calls_for_tenders/calls-for-tenders-keep-cancel-alternatives.png){.align-center}

From the `Alternative Warning`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} pop-up
window, click `Keep Alternatives`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to
keep all alternative quotations open for now. Then, click
`Requests for Quotation`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} (in the
breadcrumbs, at the top of the page) to navigate back to an overview of
all `RFQs (Requests
for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}.

Click into the remaining quotation(s) that contain products that need to
be ordered, and click `Confirm Order`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}. This causes the
`Alternative Warning`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} pop-up window
to appear again. This time, click
`Cancel Alternatives`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to cancel all
other alternative `RFQs`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} linked with this
quotation.

Finally, click `Requests for Quotation`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} (in the breadcrumbs, at the top of the page) to
navigate back to an overview of all
`RFQs (Requests for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}. The
canceled orders can be seen greyed out and listed with a
`Cancelled`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} status under the
`Status`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} column at the far right of
their rows.

Now that all product quantities have been ordered, the purchase process
can be followed, and continued to completion, until the products are
received into the warehouse.




--- SOURCE: inventory_and_mrp/purchase/manage_deals/control_bills.md ---

# Bill control policies

In Odoo, the *bill control* policy determines the quantities billed by
vendors on every purchase order, for ordered or received quantities. The
policy selected in the settings will act as the default value and will
be applied to any new product created.

## Configuration

To view the default bill control policy and make changes, go to
`Purchase -->
Configuration --> Settings`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}, and
scroll down to the `Invoicing`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
section. Here, there are the two `Bill Control`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} policy options: `Ordered quantities`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} and `Received quantities`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}.

The policy selected will be the default for any new product created. The
definition of each policy is as follows:

- `Ordered quantities`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: creates a
  vendor bill as soon as a purchase order is confirmed. The products and
  quantities in the purchase order are used to generate a draft bill.
- `Received quantities`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: a bill is
  created only *after* part of the total order has been received. The
  products and quantities *received* are used to generate a draft bill.
  An error message will appear if creation of a vendor bill is attempted
  without receiving anything.

![Bill control policy draft bill error message.](control_bills/bill-control-policy-error-message.png){.align-center}

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

If one or two products need a different control policy, the default bill
control setting can be overridden by going to the
`Purchase`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab in a product\'s
template and modifying its `Control Policy`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} field.
::::

### Example flow: Ordered quantities

To complete an example workflow using the *ordered quantities* bill
control policy, first go to
`Purchase --> Configuration --> Settings`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}, scroll down to the `Invoicing`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} section, and select
`Ordered quantities`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. Then,
`Save`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} changes.

In the `Purchase`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} app, create a new
`RFQ (Request for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}. Fill out
the information on the quotation form, add products to the invoice
lines, and click `Confirm
Order`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. Then, click
`Create Bill`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. Since the policy is
set to *ordered quantities*, the draft bill can be confirmed as soon as
it is created, without any products actually being received.

### Example flow: Received quantities

To complete an example workflow using the *received quantities* bill
control policy, first go to
`Purchase --> Configuration --> Settings`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}, scroll down to the `Invoicing`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} section, and select
`Received quantities`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. Then,
`Save`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} changes.

In the `Purchase`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} app, create a new
`RFQ (Request for Quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}. Fill out
the information on the quotation form, add products to the invoice
lines, and click `Confirm
Order`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. Then, click on the
`Receipt smart button`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. Set the
quantities in the `Done`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} column to
match the quantities in the `Demand`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
column, and `Validate`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} the changes.
Then, in the purchase order, click `Create Bill`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} and `Confirm`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. Since
the policy is set to *received quantities*, the draft bill can be
confirmed *only* when at least some of the quantities are received.

## 3-way matching

Activating `3-way matching`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} ensures
that vendor bills are only paid once some or all of the products
included in the purchase order have actually been received. To activate
it, go to `Purchase --> Configuration --> Settings`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}, and scroll down to the
`Invoicing`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} section. Then, click
`3-way matching: purchases, receptions, and
bills`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

3-way matching is *only* intended to work when the bill control policy
is set to *received quantities*.
::::

### Pay vendor bills with 3-way matching

When `3-way matching`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} is activated,
vendor bills will display the `Should Be
Paid`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field under the
`Other Info`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab. When a new vendor
bill is created, the field will be set to `Yes`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}, since a bill can\'t be created until at least some of
the products included in a purchase order have been received.

![Draft bill should be paid field status.](control_bills/vendor-bill-should-be-paid.png){.align-center}

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

If the total quantity of products from a purchase order has not been
received, Odoo only includes the products that *have* been received in
the draft vendor bill.
::::

Draft bills can be edited to increase the billed quantity, change the
price of the products in the bill, and add additional products to the
bill. If this is done, the `Should Be Paid`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} field status will be set to
`Exception`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. This means that Odoo
notices the discrepancy, but doesn\'t block the changes or display an
error message, since there might be a valid reason for making changes to
the draft bill.

Once payment has been registered for a vendor bill and displays the
green `Paid`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} banner, the
`Should Be Paid`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field status will be
set to `No`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

:::: tip
::: title
Tip
:::

The `Should Be Paid`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} status on bills
is set automatically by Odoo. However, the status can be changed
manually by clicking the field\'s drop-down menu inside the
`Other Info`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab.
::::

## View a purchase order\'s billing status

When a purchase order is confirmed, its
`Billing Status`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} can be viewed under
the `Other Information`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab on the
purchase order form.

![Purchase order billing status.](control_bills/billing-status-nothing-to-bill.png){.align-center}

Below is a list of the different statuses that a
`Billing Status`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} could appear as and
when they are displayed, depending on the bill control policy used.

+-------------------------------------+-------------------------------+--------------------------+
| `Billing Status`{.interpreted-text  | > **Conditions**                                         |
| role="guilabel"}                    |                                                          |
|                                     +-------------------------------+--------------------------+
|                                     | > *On received quantities*    | *On ordered quantities*  |
+-------------------------------------+-------------------------------+--------------------------+
| `Nothing to Bill`{.interpreted-text | > PO confirmed; no products   | > *Not applicable*       |
| role="guilabel"}                    | > received                    |                          |
+-------------------------------------+-------------------------------+--------------------------+
| `Waiting Bills`{.interpreted-text   | > All/some products received; | > PO confirmed           |
| role="guilabel"}                    | > bill not created            |                          |
+-------------------------------------+-------------------------------+--------------------------+
| `Fully Billed`{.interpreted-text    | All/some products received;   | > Draft bill created     |
| role="guilabel"}                    | draft bill created            |                          |
+-------------------------------------+-------------------------------+--------------------------+




--- SOURCE: inventory_and_mrp/purchase/manage_deals/manage.md ---

# Manage vendor bills

::: {#inventory/purchase/manage_deals/manage}
A *vendor bill* is an invoice received for products and/or services that
a company purchases from a vendor. Vendor bills record payables as they
arrive from vendors, and can include amounts owed for the goods and/or
services purchased, sales taxes, freight and delivery charges, and more.
:::

In Odoo, a vendor bill can be created at different points in the
purchasing process, depending on the *bill control* policy chosen in the
*Purchase* app settings.

## Bill control policies

To view and edit the default bill control policy and make changes to it,
go to `Purchase app --> Configuration --> Settings`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}, and scroll down to the
`Invoicing`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} section.

Here, there are two `Bill Control`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
policy options: `Ordered quantities`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
and `Received quantities`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. After a
policy is selected, click `Save`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to
save changes.

![Bill control policies in purchase app settings.](manage/manage-configuration-settings.png){.align-center}

The policy selected will be the default for any new product created. The
definition of each policy is as follows:

- `Ordered quantities`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: creates a
  vendor bill as soon as a purchase order is confirmed. The products and
  quantities in the purchase order are used to generate a draft bill.
- `Received quantities`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}: a bill is
  only created **after** part of the total order has been received. The
  products and quantities **received** are used to generate a draft
  bill.

:::: tip
::: title
Tip
:::

If a product needs a different control policy, the default bill control
policy can be overridden by going to the `Purchase`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} tab in a product\'s template, and modifying its
`Control Policy`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field.
::::

![Control policy field on product form.](manage/manage-product-form.png){.align-center}

### 3-way matching

*3-way matching* ensures vendor bills are only paid once some (or all)
of the products included in the purchase order have actually been
received.

To activate it, go to
`Purchase app --> Configuration --> Settings`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}, and scroll down to the
`Invoicing`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} section. Then, check the
box next to `3-way matching:
purchases, receptions, and bills`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
and click `Save`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to save changes.

:::: important
::: title
Important
:::

`3-way matching`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} is **only** intended
to work with the `Bill Control`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
policy set to `Received quantities`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

![Activated three-way matching feature in purchase settings.](manage/manage-three-way-matching.png){.align-center}
::::

## Create and manage vendor bills on receipts

When products are received into a company\'s warehouse, receipts are
created. Once the company processes the received quantities, they can
choose to create a vendor bill directly from the warehouse receipt form.
Depending on the bill control policy chosen in the settings, vendor bill
creation is completed at different steps of the procurement process.

### With the bill control policy set to ordered quantities

To create and manage vendor bills on receipts using the *ordered
quantities* bill control policy, first go to
`Purchase app --> Configuration --> Settings`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}, scroll down to the `Invoicing`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} section, and select
`Ordered quantities`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} under `Bill
Control`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. Then, click
`Save`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to save changes.

Next, go to the `Purchase`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"} app,
and click `Create`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to create a new
request for quotation (RFQ). Doing so reveals a blank
`RFQ (request for quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} detail
form.

On the blank detail form, add a vendor to the
`RFQ (request for quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} in the
`Vendor`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field, and add products to
the `Product`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} lines by clicking
`Add a line`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

Then, confirm the `RFQ (request for quotation)`{.interpreted-text
role="abbr"} by clicking the `Confirm Order`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} button above the detail form. Doing so turns the
`RFQ (request for quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} into a
purchase order.

Then, click the `Create Bill`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} button
to create a vendor bill for the purchase order.

Clicking the `Create Bill`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} button
reveals the `Draft Bill`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} page for the
purchase order.

On the `Draft Bill`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, click the
`Edit`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} button to modify the bill, and
add a bill date in the `Bill Date`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
field. If needed, add additional products to the
`Product`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} lines by clicking
`Add a line`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} in the
`Invoice Lines`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab.

Next, confirm the bill by clicking the `Confirm`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} button on the `Draft Bill`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} page.

:::: tip
::: title
Tip
:::

Since the bill control policy is set to *ordered quantities*, the draft
bill can be confirmed as soon as it is created, before any products have
been received.
::::

On the new `Vendor Bill`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, add a
`Bill Reference`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} number, which can be
used to match the bill with additional documents (such as the
`PO (purchase order)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}). Then, click
`Confirm --> Register Payment`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}.
Doing so causes a pop-up to appear, wherein a payment
`Journal`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} can be chosen; a
`Payment Method`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} selected; and a
`Recipient
Bank Account`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} can be selected from a
drop-down menu.

Additionally, the bill `Amount`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
`Payment Date`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and
`Memo`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
(`Reference Number`{.interpreted-text role="dfn"}) can be changed from
this pop-up. Once ready, click `Create
Payment`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to finish creating the
`Vendor Bill`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. Doing so causes a
green `In
Payment`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} banner to display on the
`RFQ (request for quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} form.

![Vendor bill form for ordered quantities control policy.](manage/manage-draft-vendor-bill.png){.align-center}

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

Each vendor bill provides the option to either
`Add Credit Note`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} or `Add
Debit Note`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. A *credit note* is
typically issued when a vendor or supplier of goods get some quantity of
products back from the customer to whom they were sold, while *debit
notes* are reserved for goods returned from the customer/buyer to the
vendor or supplier.
::::

### With the bill control policy set to received quantities

:::: warning
::: title
Warning
:::

If the creation of a vendor bill is attempted without receiving any
quantities of a product (while using the *received quantities* bill
control policy), an error message appears, and settings must be changed
before proceeding.
::::

To create and manage vendor bills on receipts using the *received
quantities* bill control policy, first go to
`Purchase app --> Configuration --> Settings`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}, scroll down to the `Invoicing`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} section, and select
`Received quantities`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} under `Bill
Control`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. Then, click
`Save`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to save changes.

Next, go to the `Purchase`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"} app,
and click `Create`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to create a new
`RFQ (request for quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}. Doing so
reveals a blank `RFQ (request for quotation)`{.interpreted-text
role="abbr"} detail form.

On the blank detail form, add a vendor to the
`RFQ (request for quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} in the
`Vendor`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field, and add products to
the `Product`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} lines by clicking
`Add a line`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

Then, confirm the `RFQ (request for quotation)`{.interpreted-text
role="abbr"} by clicking the `Confirm Order`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} button above the detail form. Doing so turns the
`RFQ (request for quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} into a
purchase order.

Finally, click the `Create Bill`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
button to create a bill for the purchase order.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

Clicking `Create Bill`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} before any
products have been received will cause a `User Error`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} pop-up to appear. The
`Purchase Order`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} requires the receipt
of at least partial quantity of the items included on the order to
create a vendor bill.
::::

![User error pop-up for received quantities control policy.](manage/manage-user-error-popup.png){.align-center}

Next, click the `Receipt`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} smart
button to view the warehouse receipt form.

On the warehouse receipt form, click
`Validate --> Apply`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"} to mark the
`Done`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} quantities. Then, navigate
back to the `Purchase Order`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}
(via the breadcrumbs), and click the `Create Bill`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} button on the purchase order form.

Doing so reveals the `Draft Bill`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} for
the purchase order. On the `Draft Bill`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}, click the `Edit`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
button, and add a `Bill Date`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. If
needed, add additional products to the `Product`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} lines by clicking `Add a line`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}.

Next, click the `Confirm`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} button to
confirm the `Draft Bill`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

Since the bill control policy is set to *received quantities*, the draft
bill can **only** be confirmed when at least some of the quantities are
received.
::::

On the new `Vendor Bill`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, add a
`Bill Reference`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} number, which can be
used to match the bill with additional documents (such as the
`PO (purchase order)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}). Then, click
`Confirm --> Register Payment`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}.
Doing so causes a pop-up to appear, wherein a payment
`Journal`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} can be chosen; a
`Payment Method`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} selected; and a
`Recipient
Bank Account`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} can be selected from a
drop-down menu.

Additionally, the bill `Amount`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
`Payment Date`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and
`Memo`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
(`Reference Number`{.interpreted-text role="dfn"}) can be changed from
this pop-up. Once ready, click `Create
Payment`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to finish creating the
vendor bill. Doing so causes a green **In Payment** banner to display on
the `RFQ (request for quotation)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} form.

## Create and manage vendor bills in Accounting

Vendor bills can also be created directly from the *Accounting* app,
**without** having to create a purchase order first. To do this, go to
`Accounting app --> Vendors --> Bills`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}, and click `Create`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}. Doing so reveals a blank vendor bill detail form.

On this blank vendor bill detail form, add a vendor in the
`Vendor`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field, and add products to
the `Product`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} lines (under the
`Invoice Lines`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} tab), by clicking
`Add a line`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}. Then, add a bill date
in the `Bill Date`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field, and any
other necessary information. Finally, click `Confirm`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} to confirm the bill.

From here, click the `Journal Items`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
tab to view (or change) the `Account`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
journals that were populated based on the configuration on the
corresponding `Vendor`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} and
`Product`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} forms.

Then, click `Add Credit Note`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} or
`Add Debit Note`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to add credit or
debit notes to the bill. Or, add a `Bill Reference`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} number (while in `Edit`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} mode).

Then, when ready, click
`Register Payment --> Create Payment`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"} to complete the `Vendor Bill`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}.

:::: tip
::: title
Tip
:::

To tie the draft bill to an existing purchase order, click the drop-down
menu next to `Auto-Complete`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}, and
select a `PO (purchase order)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"} from the
menu. The bill will auto-populate with the information from the
`PO (purchase order)`{.interpreted-text role="abbr"}.

![Auto-complete drop-down list on draft vendor bill.](manage/manage-auto-complete.png){.align-center}
::::

## Batch billing

Vendor bills can be processed and managed in batches in the *Accounting*
app.

To do this, go to
`Accounting app --> Vendors --> Bills`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}. Then, click the `checkbox`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} at the top left of the page, beside the
`Number`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} column, under the
`Create`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} button. This selects all
existing vendor bills with a `Posted`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
or `Draft`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} `Status`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"}.

From here, click the `Action`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} gear
icon to export, delete, or send & print the bills; click the
`Print`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} icon to print the invoices or
bills; or click `Register
Payment`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to create and process
payments for multiple vendor bills at once.

When `Register Payment`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} is selected,
a pop-up appears. In this pop-up window, select the appropriate journal
in the `Journal`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field, choose a
payment date in the `Payment Date`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}
field, and choose a `Payment Method`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.
There is also the option to `Group Payments`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} on this pop-up, as well.

When ready, click the `Create Payment`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} button, which creates a list of journal entries on a
separate page. This list of journal entries are all tied to their
appropriate vendor bills.

![Batch billing register payment pop-up.](manage/manage-batch-billing.png){.align-center}

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

The `Register Payment`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} option for
vendor bills in batches will only work for journal entries whose
`Status`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} is set to
`Posted`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.
::::

::: seealso
`/applications/inventory_and_mrp/purchase/manage_deals/control_bills`{.interpreted-text
role="doc"}
:::

--- SOURCE: inventory_and_mrp/purchase/products/reordering.md ---

# Configure reordering rules

For certain products, it is necessary to ensure that there is always a
minimum amount available on hand at any given time. By adding a
reordering rule to a product, it is possible to automate the reordering
process so that a purchase order is automatically created whenever the
amount on hand falls below a set threshold.

:::: important
::: title
Important
:::

The *Inventory* module must be installed to use reordering rules.
::::

## Configure products for reordering

Products must be configured in a specific way before a reordering rule
can be added to them.

Starting from the `Inventory`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"},
`Manufacturing`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"},
`Purchase`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}, or
`Sales`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"} module, navigate to
`Products
--> Products`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"} and then click
`Create`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to make a new product.
Alternatively, find a product that already exists in the database and
click into it\'s product form.

Next, on the product form, enable reordering by checking the
`Can be Purchased`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} option underneathe
the `Product Name`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field. Finally,
set the `Product Type`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} to [Storable
Product]{.title-ref} under the `General Information`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} tab.

![Configure a product for reordering in Odoo.](reordering/product-configured-for-reordering.png){.align-center}

## Add a reordering rule to a product

After properly configuring a product, a reordering rule can be added to
it by selecting the now visible `Reordering Rules`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} tab at the top of that product\'s form, and then
clicking `Create`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} on the
`Reordering Rules`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} dashboard.

![Access reordering rules for a product from the product page in Odoo.](reordering/reordering-rules-tab.png){.align-center}

Once created, the reordering rule can be configured to generate purchase
orders automatically by defining the following fields:

- `Location`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} specifies where the
  ordered quantities should be stored once they are received and entered
  into stock.

- `Min Quantity`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} sets the lower
  threshold for the reordering rule while `Max
  Quantity`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} sets the upper threshold.
  If the stock on hand falls below the minimum quantity, a new purchase
  order will be created to replenish it up to the maximum quantity.

  > ::: example
  > If `Min Quantity`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} is set to
  > [5]{.title-ref} and `Max Quantity`{.interpreted-text
  > role="guilabel"} is set to [25]{.title-ref} and the stock on hand
  > falls to four, a purchase order will be created for 21 units of the
  > product.
  > :::

- `Multiple Quantity`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} can be
  configured so that products are only ordered in batches of a certain
  quantity. Depending on the number entered, this can result in the
  creation of a purchase order that would put the resulting stock on
  hand above what is specified in the `Max
  Quantity`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} field.

  > ::: example
  > If `Max Quantity`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} is set to
  > [100]{.title-ref} but `Multiple Quantity`{.interpreted-text
  > role="guilabel"} is set to order the product in batches of
  > [200]{.title-ref}, a purchase order will be created for 200 units of
  > the product.
  > :::

- `UoM`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} specifies the unit of
  measurement by which the quantity will be ordered. For discrete
  products, this should be set to [Units]{.title-ref}. However, it can
  also be set to units of measurement like [Volume]{.title-ref} or
  [Weight]{.title-ref} for non-discrete products like water or bricks.

![Configure the reordering rule in Odoo.](reordering/reordering-rule-configuration.png){.align-center}

## Manually trigger reordering rules using the scheduler

Reordering rules will be automatically triggered by the scheduler, which
runs once a day by default. To trigger reordering rules manually,
navigate to `Inventory --> Operations
--> Run Scheduler`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}. On the
pop-up window, confirm the manual action by clicking `Run
Scheduler`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"}.

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

Manually triggering reordering rules will also trigger any other
scheduled actions.
::::

## Manage reordering rules

To manage the reordering rules for a single product, navigate to that
product page\'s form and select the `Reordering Rules`{.interpreted-text
role="guilabel"} tab at the top of the form.

To manage all reordering rules for every product, go to
`Inventory --> Configuration
--> Reordering Rules`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}. From this
dashboard, typical bulk actions in Odoo can be performed such as
exporting data or archiving rules that are no longer needed. As well,
the `Filters`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"},
`Group By`{.interpreted-text role="guilabel"} or triple-dotted menu on
the form are available to search for and/or organize the reordering
rules as desired.




--- SOURCE: inventory_and_mrp/purchase/products/uom.md ---

# Purchase in different units of measure than sales

When you purchase a product, it may happen that your vendor uses a
different unit of measure than you do when you sell it. This can cause
confusion between sales and purchase representatives. It is also
time-consuming to convert measures manually every time. With Odoo, you
can configure your product once and let Odoo handle the conversion.

Consider the following examples:

1.  You purchase orange juice from an American vendor, and they use
    **gallons**. However, your customers are European and use
    **liters**.
2.  You buy curtains from a vendor in the form of **rolls** and you sell
    pieces of the rolls to your customers using **square meters**.

## Enable units of measure

Open your Sales app and go to
`Configuration --> Settings`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}.
Under Product Catalog, enable *Units of Measure*.

![Enable the units of measure option in Odoo Sales](uom/uom-enable-option.png){.align-center}

## Specify sales and purchase units of measure

### Standard units of measure

A variety of units of measure are available by default in your database.
Each belongs to one of the five pre-configured units of measure
categories: *Length / Distance*, *Unit*, *Volume*, *Weight* and *Working
Time*.

:::: tip
::: title
Tip
:::

You can create your new units of measure and units of measure categories
(see next section).
::::

To specify different units of measures for sales and purchases, open the
Purchase app and go to `Products --> Products`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}. Create a product or select an existing one. Under
the product\'s *General Information* tab, first select the *Unit of
Measure* to be used for sales (as well as for other apps such as
inventory). Then, select the *Purchase Unit of Measure* to be used for
purchases.

Back to the first example, if you purchase orange juice from your vendor
in **gallons** and sell it to your customers in **liters**, first select
*L* (liters) as the *Unit of Measure*, and *gal (US)* (gallons) as the
*Purchase Unit of Measure*, then click on *Save*.

![Configure a product\'s units of measure in Odoo](uom/uom-product-configuration.png){.align-center}

### Create new units of measure and units of measure categories

Sometimes you need to create your own units and categories, either
because the measure is not pre-configured in Odoo or because the units
do not relate with each other (e.g. kilos and centimeters).

If you take the second example where you buy curtains from a vendor in
the form of **rolls** and you sell pieces of the rolls using **square
meters**, you need to create a new *Units of Measure Category* in order
to relate both units of measure.

To do so, go to
`Configuration --> Units of Measure Categories`{.interpreted-text
role="menuselection"}. Click on *Create* and name the category.

![Create a new units of measure category in Odoo Purchase](uom/uom-new-category.png){.align-center}

The next step is to create the two units of measures. To do so, go to
`Configuration
--> Units of Measure`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}.

First, create the unit of measure used as the reference point for
converting to other units of measure inside the category by clicking on
*Create*. Name the unit and select the units of measure category you
just created. For the *Type*, select *Reference Unit of Measure for this
category type*. Enter the *Rounding Precision* you would like to use.
The quantity computed by Odoo is always a multiple of this value.

In the example, as you cannot purchase less than 1 roll and won\'t use
fractions of a roll as a unit of measure, you can enter 1.

![Create a new reference unit of measure in Odoo Purchase](uom/uom-new-reference-unit.png){.align-center}

:::: note
::: title
Note
:::

If you use a *Rounding Precision* inferior to 0.01, a warning message
might appear stating that it is higher than the *Decimal Accuracy* and
that it might cause inconsistencies. If you wish to use a *Rounding
Precision* lower than 0.01, first activate the `developer mode
<developer-mode>`{.interpreted-text role="ref"}, then go to
`Settings --> Technical --> Database Structure -->
Decimal Accuracy`{.interpreted-text role="menuselection"}, select
*Product Unit of Measure* and edit *Digits* accordingly. For example, if
you want to use a rounding precision of 0.00001, set *Digits* to 5.
::::

Next, create a second unit of measure, name it, and select the same
units of measure category as your reference unit. As *Type*, select
*Smaller* or *Bigger than the reference Unit of Measure*, depending on
your situation.

As the curtain roll equals to 100 square meters, you should select
*Smaller*.

Next, you need to enter the *Ratio* between your reference unit and the
second one. If the second unit is smaller, the *Ratio* should be greater
than 1. If the second unit is larger, the ratio should be smaller than
1.

For your curtain roll, the ratio should be set to 100.

![Create a second unit of measure in Odoo Purchase](uom/uom-second-unit.png){.align-center}

You can now configure your product just as you would using Odoo\'s
standard units of measure.

![Set a product\'s units of measure using your own units in Odoo Purchase](uom/uom-product-configuration-new-units.png){.align-center}
